subject: Re: [junit] REQ: Pro side of "use inner classes to test    private stuff"
msgSnippet: ... Why not? I have Javadoc that happens to describe the private parts. I can use JUnitX to get at the private parts. ... in this case, the nested class idea
messageBody:
>So said Alain Ravet on 2003-08-07 --------------------
>J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
>>Now suppose you don't have the source and need to replace the entire
>legacy component with a new component that has equivalent behavior? (I
>know it's a different scenario than building a safety net for refactoring.)
>>
>>Any comments? Thanks.
>>
>>
>You lost me there, if we're still in the same thread: if you don't have
>the source, you can't see nor test its private (inner) parts.

Why not? I have Javadoc that happens to describe the private parts. I can use JUnitX to get at the private parts. ... in this case, the "nested class" idea goes away because there's no way to graft nested parts onto the original.

Good point. This is why I ask. I have no pair partner here.

>About your new question, it looks like the classical "use the original
>as a test" case :
>I'd build a series of Client Tests around it, to understand its
>behavour, and use them to build/test the new component.
>There are many variations here, whether you start from scratch, or
>extends the original and override it progressively.

That's pretty much what I would do, as well.

>Does it answer your question?

Yes. Thanks for your help.
